Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Changes in tropical forest farming under conditions of rapid socio-ecological restructuring

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Tropical rainforests are being transformed into many different kinds of agricultural production systems. As these forests are transformed so too are the livelihoods people obtain from them. This project explores what factors drive the rainforest cultivation through an agricultural practice known as agroforestry in light of various environmental pressures. This project trains a graduate student in rigorous techniques of scientific, mixed-methods environmental anthropology. This research will contribute to the growing scientific exploration of the role of agroforestry in the livelihood of rural people and maintenance of tropical forests. Project findings will potentially aid environmental and land use policy makers through detailed analysis of agricultural and ecological processes in a region of the world that is of recognized environmental, cultural and political significance.

Stanford University doctoral candidate, David Gilbert, advised by Dr. William Durham, will examine how forest farmers have countered competing pressures on their forestlands to create inhabited agroforests. This project uses environmental anthropology methods to better understand this type of working forest, with implications for the social and environmental sustainability of agricultural commodity crop production more generally. As site of globally important agricultural commodity markets and millions of forest farmers Sumatra is an ideal region for the study of agroforestry. Research is focused in two forest farmer settlements in Sumatra's Bukit Barisan mountain range. Both settlements cultivate agroforests that provide a range of valuable commodities. Preliminary data analysis shows that the social ecology of agroforests allows forest farmers flexible integration into global agricultural commodities markets. To better characterize this agroforestry adaptation and practice, Mr. Gilbert will use participant observation, in-depth interviews and an agroecological survey. Ecological changes will be described by constructing a Geographic Informations Systems database of land use. This research will contribute to understanding of the ways rural people respond to political and economic influences, and the ways these responses may drive ecological change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the support of the National Science Foundation, I proposed to study how family-farmers in Sumatra countered competing pressures on to create inhabited, economically-valuable agroforests. Over a nine month research period, I used environmental anthropology methods on Sumatra’s Aren volcano to investigate how one group of agriculturalists was able to rehabilitate degraded land and cultivate expanding mixed-species woodlands that support ecological process and produce a range of valuable commodities. Participant observation, ethnography, a household agro-ecological survey and the analysis of archival documents and satellite photography were completed.

My results indicate that a central challenge to modern family farmers is establishing the political economic space to farm as agriculture becomes ever-more industrialized. Analysis of archival documents, oral histories and interviews demonstrate that family farmers on Aren overcame this challenge by gaining access to the land through political process and agricultural activity. Family-farmers appealed to ideas of customary land use and the economic productivity of smallholder agriculture to persuade the government to allow this access. The family-farmers then reconstituted a land commons, where their agricultural land was owned and managed in collective by a deliberative council. Collective ownership encouraged family-farmers to cooperate in the process of establishing land tenure and management of the land. It also prevented any consolidation of the small-scale agricultural plots into industrial-scale agriculture.

As part of a long history of land use changes, Aren’s family-farmers now cultivate land that had been degraded by previous cattle grazing and plantation agriculture. Landsat and Corona satellite photography spanning this period demonstrate the trend toward decreasing forest cover and increased exposed soils - leading to their degradation. Participant observation, interviews and agro-ecological survey data show that Aren’s forest-farmers turned to agroforestry to rehabilitate the land, illustrating the unique characteristics of agroforests that support soil health, high productivity and watershed function. Landsat and WorldView satellite imagery spanning forest-farmers reclaiming show small-scale reforestation and a smallholder landscape mosaic full of flux and heterogeneity. My results leave no doubt that agroforestry is but a part of a broader agroecology that Aren’s forest-farmers practice. This agroecology livelihood includes wet-rice, vegetable gardens, agroforestry, small-scale livestock rearing and wage labor. Such agroecological diversification allows family farmers flexible integration into global agricultural commodities markets.

A micro - scale investigation of the differential abilities of agriculturalists to access the moribund plantation land and successfully apply agroecological principles upon it shows that the question of how rural places develop can not be collapsed into a question of agricultural productivity alone. Agroecological knowledge, power, gender, and community leaders' proscription of who properly 'belongs to the land' have determined which of the agriculturalists have flourished and which have not. Yet it would be a mistake to overlook the general trend that the events on the Aren volcano represent. Agriculturalists are increasingly established thriving agroecology as part of a 'post industrial' agricultural economy. This trend is the thread connecting family-farmers in Minnesota with those in Sumatra. All work to increase plant diversity, soil health and diversify production while minimizing inputs of all kinds - from fertilizers and pesticides to financial transactions that can lead to debt.

This agroecological 'mind towards polyculture' supports more than economic security. In Aren, a patchwork of small-scale agroforests mimic natural rainforest while providing the disturbance and landscape heterogeneity that supports biodiversity. The mimicry is achieved by harnessing ecological process. Agroecology relies ecologically informed cultivar selection and spatial and temporal management to maximize yields on a given plot of land across time and three-dimensional space (from canopy to tree roots). This humanized nature tends to the kind of ‘intermediate disturbance’ that has recently been shown to support the highest levels of biodiversity in tropical rainforest landscapes. The potential of these humanized natures across the rural world indicate that unidirectional ideas of development that ends only with rural industrialization are incomplete. Counter-trajectories of development exist, where multiplicitous agroecological production takes rural industrialization as not an endpoint but instead a waypoint towards a more livable future.
